thread.title: Fine Gael minister argues coalition with Fianna Fail would make economic 'situation an awful lot worse'
thread.title_full: Fine Gael minister argues coalition with Fianna Fail would make economic 'situation an awful lot worse'

author: David Maher
title: Fine Gael minister argues coalition with Fianna Fail would make economic 'situation an awful lot worse'
text:
Fine Gael minister argues coalition with Fianna Fail would make economic 'situation an awful lot worse' 17:04, 26 Oct 2015 Jobs, Enterprise and Innovation Minister Richard Bruton totally opposed to going into government with rivals   Thanks   Richard Bruton doesn't think getting into bed with Fianna Fail is a good idea 
Fine Gael Minister Richard Bruton has said he would be totally opposed to his party forming a coalition with Fianna Fail in the next General Election. 
The Minister for Jobs, Enterprise and Innovation said he believed the Irish public would make the right decision closer to election time and would shun Fianna Fail. 
Minister Bruton was speaking on RTE’s Morning Ireland ahead of a trade mission to the East Coast of the United States. 
He said: “I would be totally opposed to such an approach, I think you’re suggesting we seek to form an alliance with the party which put us into the mess we’re in. 
“Do we go back to the party that put us into the mess? Do we go to the party who, in my belief, would make the situation an awful lot worse?" 
A favourable budget saw support for Fine Gael rise by two points to 30% compared with September, the first time in almost three years the party has reached this level. 
Support fell for the other half of the Coalition however, as Labour suffered a three point decline to 7% compared with last month. 
If these results were replicated in the general election the current Coalition would be unable to secure the necessary seats to remain in office without support from Independents or at least one other party. 
Meanwhile, Fianna Fail has gained 2 points and now stands at 20%. Gareth Chaney Collins Fianna Fail Leader Micheal Martin: Would he be prepared to do a deal with Enda Kenny? 
Labour’s continued hemorrhaging of support has fuelled speculation that Fine Gael may need the support of Fianna Fail, their long time rivals, to form a stable government. 
Taoiseach Enda Kenny stressed the need for sustained recovery telling his party’s presidential dinner recently that it must “sustain the recovery” instead of handing it over to rival parties. 
Mr Kenny said: “I, for one, don’t want to see Ireland’s hard-won progress put at risk by those who wrecked our economy several times in the past, or by those whose policies would surely wreck it in the future. 
“Fine Gael has a plan to keep the recovery going. 
“It’s a plan based on enterprise, not speculation.” 
Minister Bruton admitted that he in unconcerned by Labour’s ailing support. 
He added: “Both parties (Fine Gael and Labour) have lost support, people have been through a very difficult period, people have suffered a lot that is the reality. 
“Every poll is different and as we get closer to the election I think people will look at the alternatives and stick with a policy mix that is seeing our roads being busier, our restaurants fuller, and all our sectors showing good signs of recovery.” Are Fine Gael and Fianna Fail destined to form a Government together? Let us know in our new comments section below
